PMP RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN



1.  The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies.



The Jackson County Utility Authority's Emergency Response Plan is used to provide clear, consise directions during an emergency.  Its function is to prevent physical harm to the staff, the public, or the plant facilities.



This plan is a key to preparedness and was developed using EPA guidelines.  The Emergency Response Plan includes a series of action plans for specific situations and lists emergency supplies, emergency organizations, and emergency telephone numbers.



The Emergency Response Plan is comprised of the following action plans for emergency situations:



*  Emergency Telephone Numbers

*  First Aid Procedures

*  Chemical Emergencies

*  Electrical Emergencies

*  Weather Emergencies

*  Material Safety Data Sheets



Insofar as possible, every contingency has been covered under the Authority's Emergency Response Plan.



The Authority's wastewater treatment facilities have safety systems for the prevention of an accidental release.  These systems include the following:



*  Leak Detector System

*  Automatic Emergency Shut off System

*  Manual Shut off System

*  Call-Out System

*  Safety Inspections



The leak detector system monitors the chlorine/sulfur dioxide storage area and the feed control station inside the building for chemical leaks.  In the event of a chlorine or sulfur dioxide leak, the leak detector will activate an audible alarm horn and warning light signifying the type of leak, chlorine or sulfur dioxide, and the leak location, storage area or control station. The Automatic Emergency Shut off system operates and automatic valve shutoff actuator that will shut down the gas system upon leak detection. The activated system will alert plant personnel, who are on duty 24 hours a day.  Plant personnel will then implement the necessary leak procedure as per the Emergency Response Plan

.



The safety inspections are conducted by the Authority's Safety Committee on a semi-annual basis for overall plant safety and awareness.  Plant operators conduct monthly safety inspections on the chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems to insure all equipment is in proper working condition.  Any discrepancies found during the inspections are corrected immediately.



With the use of these safety systems, the Authority provides safety of not only plant personnel, but the community around the facilities.



2.  The stationary source and regulated substance handled.



The JCUA POTW 7C (Pascagoula/Moss Point) Regional Wastewater Treatment Plant treats domestic wastewater from the cities of Pascagoula and Moss Point.



Chlorine is applied to the treatment plant effluent for the purpose of disinfection and sulfur dioxide is used for chlorine removal prior to discharge to the Pascagoula River.



The facility stores two one-ton containers of chlorine and two one-ton containers of sulfur dioxide. This equates to a four month supply of chlorine and a three month supply of sulfur dioxide at present operating conditions. The facility operates with one container of chlorine and sulfur dioxide on line and one container of chlorine and sulfur dixoide on standby.



3.  The worst-case release scenario:



The worst-case release scenario was based on the complete breakage of a pipe connected to a storage container containing 2,000 pounds of chlorine, with a 10 minute release time.



Utilizing urban conditions with a wind speed of 1.5 meters per second, class F stability, the toxic end point would be 0.0087 at a distance of 1.3 miles.



The residential population within this distance is 5,015.  Public and environmental receptors within the distance that would be affected include schools, prisons, recreational areas, industrial areas, state parks, and monuments.



Alternate-case release scenario number one:



The alternate-case release scenario was based on a 1/4 inch (.0625) p

uncture in a pipe connected to a storage container containing 2,000 pounds of chlorine, with a 10 minute release time.



Utilizing urban conditions with a wind speed of 3.0 meters per second, class D stability, the toxic end point would be 0.0087 at a distance of 0.3 miles.



The residential population within this distance is less than 100.  Public and environmental receptors within the distance that would be affected include business, recreational areas, and industrial areas.



The chlorine/sulfur dioxide building is covered and partially enclosed.  This minimizes the potential for overheating of the ton container.



The gas feeder on the chlorine container is designed to shut off the supply of gas in case of a line breakage.



The chlorine/sulfur dioxide building is also equipped with a leak detector system.  In the event of a leak, an automatic shut off system will shut down the valve and an alarm will activate, alerting the plant personnel.  Following automatic shut-down, plant personnel will respond in accordance with the Emergency Response Plan.



4.  The accidental release prevention program.



There are several key steps to the JCUA POTW 7C Regional Wastewater Treatment plant's prevention plan.



*  Maintenance Service Agreement (changes out valve and regulators)

*  Call-Out System

*  Leak Detector System

*  Safety Inspections

*  Safety Training



5.  Five-year accident history.



The JCUA POTW 7C Regional Wastewater Treatment plant has not had an accidental release of chlorine or sulfur dioxide over the past five years.



6.  Emergency Response Program.



The Authority participates in the Community Right to Know, SARA Title III, Tier 2 program.  The JCUA participates in the EPlan Hazmat Emergency Response system online reporting notified by Tier II  Reporting system that is required by the EPA. E-Plan is a proven system that provides First Responders and others with on-site hazardous chemical information for facilities around the United Stat

es.  It utilized emergency contact and hazardous material information submitted under the US Environmental Protection Agency regulations and sends it via the internet to First Responders just when they need it the most. This facility ifnormation is also provided to the the Jackson County Office of Emergency Services and the Gautier Fire Department.



7.  Safety Improvements.



The Authority installed the automatic shut off system in 2016.The Authority installed new chlorination and declorination equipment in September, 2006.  Along with the new equipment, new chlorine and sulfur dioxide leak detectors were installed for enhanced monitoring of chlorine or sulfur dioxide leaks.  In 2002, a reduction in on hand quantities of chlorine and sulfur dioxide at the plant sight was implemented.
